The '''All Circuit Review Extension Act''' ({{USBill|113|hr|4197}}; {{uspl|113|170}}) is a bill that would extend for three years the authority for federal employees who appeal a judgment of the [[Merit Systems Protection Board]] (MSPB) to file their appeal at any federal court, instead of only the [[United States courts of appeals|U.S. Court of Appeals]].<ref name="cbo4197"/> This was a pilot program established in the [[Whistleblower Protection Act#Whistleblower Protection Enhancement Act and Presidential Policy Directive 19|Whistleblower Protection Enhancement Act of 2012]] to last only two years.
The bill was introduced into the [[United States House of Representatives]] during the [[113th United States Congress]]. The bill was signed into law.
==Background== The pilot program was established in the [[Whistleblower Protection Act#Whistleblower Protection Enhancement Act and Presidential Policy Directive 19|Whistleblower Protection Enhancement Act of 2012]] (WPEA) to last only two years. The [[Government Accountability Project]] (GAP) calls the program "landmark" and says that it was "the WPEA's most significant structural reform."<ref name=GAPpendLeg>{{cite web|title=Pending Legislation|url=http://www.whistleblower.org/pending-legislation|publisher=Government Accountability Project|accessdate=15 July 2014}}</ref>
==Provisions of the bill== ''This summary is based largely on the summary provided by the [[Congressional Research Service]], a [[public domain]] source.''<ref name=4197sum>{{cite web|title=H.R. 4197 - Summary|url=https://beta.congress.gov/bill/113th-congress/house-bill/4197|publisher=United States Congress|accessdate=15 July 2014}}</ref>
The All Circuit Review Extension Act would extend from two to five years after the effective date of the [[Whistleblower Protection Act#Whistleblower Protection Enhancement Act and Presidential Policy Directive 19|Whistleblower Protection Enhancement Act of 2012]] (i.e., December 27, 2012), the period allowed for: (1) filing a petition for judicial review of [[Merit Systems Protection Board]] decisions in [[whistleblower]] cases, and (2) any review of such a decision by the Director of the [[Office of Personnel Management]] (OPM).<ref name="4197sum"/>
==Congressional Budget Office report== ''This summary is based largely on the summary provided by the [[Congressional Budget Office]], as ordered reported by the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform on March 12, 2014. This is a [[public domain]] source.''<ref name=cbo4197>{{cite web|title=CBO - H.R. 4197|url=http://www.cbo.gov/publication/45233|publisher=Congressional Budget Office|accessdate=15 July 2014}}</ref>
The [[Congressional Budget Office]] (CBO) estimates that enacting H.R. 4197 would have no significant effect on the federal budget. The legislation could affect direct spending by agencies not funded through the annual appropriations (such as the [[Tennessee Valley Authority]]); therefore, [[PAYGO|pay-as-you-go]] procedures apply. CBO estimates, however, that any net increase in spending by those agencies would not be significant. Enacting the bill would not affect revenues.<ref name="cbo4197"/>
H.R. 4197 would extend for three years the authority for federal employees who appeal a judgment of the Merit Systems Protection Board (MSPB) to file their appeal at any federal court, instead of only the [[United States courts of appeals|U.S. Court of Appeals]]. Based on information from MSPB and the [[United States Office of Special Counsel|Office of Special Counsel]], CBO expects that allowing appeals to be filed in any federal circuit would lead to a small increase in the administrative burden of the MSPB and federal agencies. We estimate, however, that the costs associated with that increase would not be significant.<ref name="cbo4197"/>
H.R. 4197 contains no intergovernmental or private-sector mandates as defined in the [[Unfunded Mandates Reform Act]] and would impose no costs on state, local, or tribal governments.<ref name="cbo4197"/>
==Procedural history== The Al Circuit Review Extension Act was introduced on March 11, 2014 by [[Elijah Cummings|Rep. Elijah E. Cummings (D, MD-7)]].<ref name=4197allactions>{{cite web|title=H.R. 4197 - All Actions|url=https://beta.congress.gov/bill/113th-congress/house-bill/4197/all-actions|publisher=United States Congress|accessdate=15 July 2014}}</ref> The bill was referred to the [[United States House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform]], the [[United States House Committee on the Judiciary]], and the [[United States House Judiciary Subcommittee on Regulatory Reform, Commercial and Antitrust Law]]. On July 14, 2014, it was reported alongside House Report 113-519 part 1.<ref name="4197allactions"/> The House voted on July 14, 2014 to pass the bill in a [[voice vote]].<ref name="4197allactions"/>
==Debate and discussion== The organization [[Government Accountability Project]] (GAP) supported the legislation, arguing that an extension of the pilot program was needed in order to ensure that the [[Government Accountability Office]] (GAO) and Congress had enough time to see the results of the program before deciding whether to make it permanent.<ref name="GAPpendLeg"/>
[[Federal Employed Women]] (FEW) and the [[Make It Safe Coalition]] supported the passage of the bill. They argued that "all circuit review is a sorely needed provision to ensure that the WPEA is enforced as Congress intended" because "during its 1982-2012 monopoly the Federal Circuit rewrote and gutted congressionally-passed whistleblower rights repeatedly."<ref name=FEWsupport>{{cite web|title=Coalition Applauds Committee Vote to Extend Whistleblower Rights|url=https://www.few.org/coalition-applauds-committee-vote-extend-whistleblower-rights/|publisher=Federally Employed Women|accessdate=15 July 2014}}</ref> The Coalition reported that "the Federal Circuit had a 3-226 record against whistleblowers for decisions on the merits since October 1994, making it all but impossible for a whistleblower to prevail in court."<ref name="FEWsupport"/>
Rep. Elijah Cummings, who introduced the bill, said that this program is important to extend because it "allows whistleblowers to file appeals where they live rather than being limited to the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals."<ref name=CommitPR1>{{cite web|title=Oversight Committee Passes Bipartisan Bills to Improve Federal Worker Savings, Whistleblower Protections|url=http://oversight.house.gov/release/oversight-committee-passes-bipartisan-bills-improve-federal-worker-savings-whistleblower-protections/|publisher=House Committee on Oversight & Government Reform|accessdate=15 July 2014|date=12 March 2014}}</ref> He also said that the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals has "an abysmal track record in whistleblower cases."<ref name="CommitPR1"/>
Rep. [[Darrell Issa]] also supported the bill, arguing that "whistleblowers are a critical asset for congressional oversight" and that extending the pilot program would give Congress "more time to gauge the impact of an 'all circuit' review."<ref name="CommitPR1"/>
==See also== *[[List of bills in the 113th United States Congress]] *[[Whistleblower protection in the United States]]

The '''[http://www.abi.org American Bankruptcy Institute]''' is an organization of over 13,000 bankruptcy and insolvency professionals, including attorneys, judges, law professors, accountants, investment bankers and turn-around specialists. It bills itself as the "largest multi-disciplinary, non-partisan organization dedicated to research and education on matters related to insolvency."<ref>1 {{cite web|url=http://www.abiworld.org/AM/Template.cfm?Section=About_ABI|title=About ABI}}</ref>
The ABI disseminates information by organizing conferences and publishing scholarly journals, including the [[American Bankruptcy Institute Law Review]]. It also holds panels bringing together multiple viewpoints on particular issues relating to insolvency.<ref>2 {{cite web|url=http://www.bankruptcylawreview.com/blog/private-equity-firms-and-hedge-funds|title=The Role of the Hedge Fund in Corporate Restructurings: White Knight or Villain?|access-date=2013-02-21|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130226050621/http://bankruptcylawreview.com/blog/private-equity-firms-and-hedge-funds|archive-date=2013-02-26|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> In addition, the ABI has established a commission to study and propose reforms to Chapter 11 law governing bankruptcies.<ref>3 {{cite web|url=http://commission.abi.org/purpose-commission|title=Purpose of the Commission}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}

{{Infobox |name = Asia Cup Moot |bodystyle = width:20em |titlestyle = |title = Asia Cup Moot |image = [[File:Seal_of_the_Ministry_of_Foreign_Affairs_of_Japan.jpg|200px]] |caption = |headerstyle = |labelstyle = width:33% |datastyle = |header1 = | label1 = Established | data1 = 1999 | label2 = Venue | data2 = [[Tokyo]] | label3 = Subject matter | data3 = [[Public international law]] | label4 = Class | data4 = Regional | label5 = Record participation | data5 = 40 teams (2011) | label6 = Qualification | data6 = National rounds (memorials) | label7 = Most championships | data7 = [[National University of Singapore Faculty of Law|National University of Singapore]] (6) | label8 = Website | data8 = http://asiacup.sakura.ne.jp/ }} The '''Asia Cup Moot''', or '''Asia Cup''' in short, is an annual international [[moot court]] competition that is open to law schools in Asia. The competition inaugurated in 1999 and is held in Tokyo, Japan. It is jointly organised by the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan]] and the International Law Students Exchange Council, and the moot problem typically contains issues pertaining to [[public international law]], [[international humanitarian law]], and [[international human rights]].http://www.mofa.go.jp/announce/event/2005/8/0801.htmlhttp://www.smu.edu.sg/sites/default/files/smu/news_room/smu_in_the_news/2011/sources/ST_20110902_2.pdfhttp://www.smu.edu.sg/sites/default/files/smu/news_room/smu_in_the_news/2014/sources/aug25/ST_20140823_2.pdfhttp://www.np.emb-japan.go.jp/ann/070213.htmlhttp://www.hukumonline.com/berita/baca/lt522de429c303b/fh-unpad-sabet-dua-gelar-di-asia-cup The top 10–12 scoring teams for the memorials qualify for the international rounds in Tokyo, but generally each country except Japan is only permitted to send one team.http://kokusaiho.aquasky.jp/en/index.htm Each team may feature up to four oralists. As of 2017, 45 different law schools have competed in Tokyo since the moot's inception. For some schools, the moot (as is the Red Cross International Humanitarian Law Moot in Hong Kong) is seen as a rite of passage for Asian mooters before they go on to participate in the larger international moots, such as the [[Philip C. Jessup International Law Moot Court Competition|Jessup Moot]] and [[Willem C. Vis Moot|Vis Moot]]. [[National University of Singapore Faculty of Law|National University of Singapore]] is the most successful schools winning six championships. The Philippines and Singapore, with nine wins each, are the winningest countries. Since 2010, Singapore has dominated the moot, with NUS taking the last three championships, and [[SMU School of Law|Singapore Management University]] reaching the international finals six years in a row between 2010 and 2015—winning three—and having 12 of its oralists ranked in the top 5 for Best Oralist. ==Competition records== {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor=#efefef | '''Year''' || '''Total number of teams''' || '''Champion (win number)''' || '''Runner-up (win number)''' || '''Top 5 oralists (win number)''' || '''Top 5 memorials (win number)''' || '''International debut''' |- | 2018 || 30+ || [[National University of Singapore Faculty of Law|National University of Singapore]] (6) || [[University of Malaya]] (2) || || || |- | 2017http://asiacup.sakura.ne.jp/p2017.html || 30+ || National University of Singapore (5) || [[Thammasat University]] (1) || * 1st: National University of Singapore (3)

{{Multiple issues| {{Underlinked|date=June 2016}} {{Orphan|date=August 2015}} {{third party|date=July 2018}} }} {{Infobox organization|name = Association of Judicial Unity (YBD)|image =|image_size = 250|location = Cinnah Caddesi Piyade Sokak No 13 ÇANKAYA / ANKARA|membership = 4154 Members|sec_gen = Dr. Birol KIRMAZ|leader_name = İlhan AYAZ-Harun KODALAK-Ayhan AKYÜREK|website = www.ybd.org.tr|twitter = yargidabirlik|facebook = Yargıda-Birlik-Derneği|formation = {{start date and age|2015|03|27}}}} '''Association of Judicial Unity (YBD)''' [jbd̪] is the largest association of judges and [[public prosecutor]]s in [[Turkey]]. YBD’s origins date back to the Platform of the Judicial Unity created in 2014 by judges and prosecutors from all political horizons, philosophical convictions and religious beliefs. Ensuring the same spirit of heterogeneity, YBD has obtained the legal status of association on March 27, 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.ybd.org.tr/en/ybd-hakkinda/tarihce|title=Yargıda Birlik Derneği is under construction|website=www.ybd.org.tr}}{{cite web|url=http://www.haber7.com/hukuk/haber/1331389-yargida-birlik-platformu-dernek-oldu|title=Yargıda Birlik Platformu dernek oldu|first=|last=Haber7|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ulusalkanal.com.tr/gundem/yargida-birlik-dernegi-kuruldu-h54664.html|title=Yargıda Birlik Derneği kuruldu haberi - Son Dakika Haberleri|first=Ulusal|last=Kanal|website=www.ulusalkanal.com.tr}} == History == Founded in 2014 by members of the judiciary concerned about the future of the judicial system in Turkey, the Platform of the Judicial Unity has evolved to become the Association of Judicial Unity on March 27, 2015. The conception bringing the platform into existence has been maintained during the creation of YBD. The members of YBD undertake to make efforts in order to protect the independence and impartiality of the judiciary and thus preserving the public trust in the judiciary by taking a stance equidistant to all kinds of political opinions, philosophical or religious beliefs and convictions. YBD’s first General Assembly meeting was held on September 12, 2015. == Aims and vision == According to the Charter, YBD’s objectives and principles can be summarized as follows; The [[Rule of Law]], which is one of the fundamental values of modern [[democracy]], will only be possible with a strong judicial power. Such a strong judicial power requires ensuring the independence, impartiality and accountability of the judiciary. In this connection, independence of the judiciary, which is a prerequisite for the rule of law, serves as a guarantee for the right to a fair trial and also as a fundamental guarantee of a democratic society. The notion of independence, which finds its meaning in the Constitution and which is also mentioned in the international instruments, makes it essential that one acts in accordance with the Constitution and the laws and only and solely on his/her personal conviction and that no adherence to any other person, institution or formation is allowed. Independence from the public opinion and non-judicial government institutions must be ensured and maintained. Independence must be secured within the judiciary as well. The notion of impartiality refers to the necessity that members of the judiciary must, in compliance with the law without any influence during the decision-making processes, adopt an equitable approach to parties. Accordingly, it is incumbent on the State to enable the execution of judicial activities without any inherent fear or distress, and judges and prosecutors have also their share of responsibility in this regard. Another issue of importance as for a democratic rule of law is the accountability and transparency. Independence and impartiality could develop into an identity, which is in conformity with democracy, only through the mechanisms of accountability. The Association of Judicial Unity ("YBD") has emerged as a civil initiative of the members of the judiciary with a view to exerting efforts in this regard. The understanding bringing YBD into existence is to protect the [[Judicial independence|independence]] and impartiality of the judiciary and thus to maintain the public trust in the judiciary, without adopting any political stance and by avoiding from political disputes. YBD has aimed to provide all kinds of efforts for a judicial administration which would afford a working environment free from threats and oppression within the judiciary; eliminate and satisfy all of the concerns and expectations as regards the issues of assignment, transfer, authorization, promotion and inspection; and adopt an approach responsive to individual or family-related requests of members of the judiciary. YBD will carry out works with a view to developing an effective and well-functioning judiciary system which has internalized the human rights and which takes as basis only the public trust and public satisfaction. It will also observe the satisfaction of members of the judiciary and judicial staff. In this context, activities will be carried out for the purposes of ensuring that the judiciary system adopts new practices, that the working conditions are improved, that the judiciary comes to a point which enables it to cope with the case-load and that the communication between judicial institutions and other judicial actors is improved; and proposals will be developed in order to achieve judicial excellence. The main character of this formation consists of a participatory approach and an understanding of taking a stance equidistant to all kinds of political opinions, philosophical or religious beliefs and convictions. The pre-eminence of the rights and the rule of law are the indispensable aims pursued by YBD. The members of YBD undertake to make efforts in order to maintain this structure, and to observe the independence and impartiality of the judiciary as well as the tenure of judges. YBD will conduct its works by taking the following instruments as basis: the [[Constitution of Turkey|Constitution of the Republic of Turkey]], the [[European Convention on Human Rights]], the United Nations Basic Principles on the Independence of the Judiciary, the United Nations Principles on the Role of Prosecutors, the Council of Europe Recommendation on Independence, Efficiency and Role of Judges; the European Charter on the Statute for Judges, the United Nations Bangalore Principles of Judicial Conduct; Recommendations of the Committee of Minister of the Council of Europe and the Consultative Council of European Judges (CCJE), the Universal Charter of the Judge, the [[Budapest Principles]] adopted for prosecutors, the [[United Nations Convention against Corruption]] (UNCAC), the Criminal Law Convention on Corruption, and other relevant international instruments and standards.{{cite web|url=http://www.ybd.org.tr/en/ybd-hakkinda/misyon-ve-vizyon|title=Yargıda Birlik Derneği is under construction|website=www.ybd.org.tr}} == Membership== There are two categories of membership with YBD.{{cite web|url=http://www.ybd.org.tr/en/ybd-hakkinda/uyelik-kosullari|title=Yargıda Birlik Derneği is under construction|website=www.ybd.org.tr}} === Invitation to Membership === Honorary membership may be granted by the decision of the Board of Directors to those who are not entitled to have the right to full membership, but are showing commitment, both in Turkey and abroad, to the principles and objectives of YBD and make contributions for the achievement of its objectives. === Direct Application for Membership === Persons who are eligible for full membership in YBD and are willing to be a member of YBD shall be required to indicate names and member ID numbers of at least three members of YBD who could invite him or her to membership. == Bodies Of YBD{{cite web|url=http://www.ybd.org.tr/en/ybd-hakkinda/yonetim|title=Yargıda Birlik Derneği is under construction|website=www.ybd.org.tr}} == Administrative Committee === Chairmanship Council === *İlhan AYAZ

{{Infobox judge |name = Augusto Antonio Barbera |image = Augusto Antonio Barbera.jpg |alt = 180px |office = Judge of the [[Constitutional Court of Italy]] |term_start = 21 December 2015 |term_end = |appointer = [[Italian Parliament]] |predecessor = |successor = |office2 = [[Italian Minister for Parliamentary Relations|Minister for Parliamentary Relations]] |term_start2 = 29 April 1993 |term_end2 = 4 May 1993 |primeminister2 = [[Carlo Azeglio Ciampi]] |predecessor2 = [[Egidio Sterpa]] |successor2 = [[Paolo Barile]] |office3 = Member of the [[Chamber of Deputies (Italy)|Chamber of Deputies]] |term_start3 = 5 July 1976 |term_end3 = 14 April 1994 |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1938|06|25|df=yes}} |birth_place = [[Aidone]], Italy |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Italian Communist Party|PCI]] (until 1991)
[[Democratic Party of the Left|PDS]] (1991-1998)
[[Democrats of the Left|DS]] (1998-2007)
[[Democratic Party (Italy)|PD]] (since 2007) |nationality = Italian |alma_mater = [[University of Catania]] |}} '''Augusto Antonio Barbera''' (born 25 June 1938) is an Italian judge and former [[constitutional law]] professor at the [[University of Bologna]]. In his political career he was member of the [[Chamber of Deputies (Italy)|Chamber of Deputies]] between 1976 and 1994 for the [[Italian Communist Party]] and later the [[Democratic Party of the Left]]. In 1993 he served shortly as Minister without portfolio for relations with Parliament in the government of Prime Minister [[Carlo Azeglio Ciampi]]. Barbera has been Judge of the [[Constitutional Court of Italy]] since 21 December 2015. ==Career== Barbera was born in [[Aidone]] on 25 June 1938.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.cortecostituzionale.it/ActionPagina_321.do |title=The Constitutional Court: Composition of the Court |publisher=Constitutional Court of Italy |date= |accessdate=4 April 2016}} He obtained a degree in Jurisprudence with a specialization in constitutional law. Between 1967 and 1969 he worked abroad as a researcher at the universities of [[Karlsruhe Institute of Technology|Karlsruhe]] and [[Heidelberg University|Heidelberg]].{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.cortecostituzionale.it/documenti/interventi_presidente/Criscuolo_laudatio3_bis.pdf |title=Discurso di benvenuto del Presidente dott. Allesandro Criscuolo ai Giudici constituzionali Franco Modugno, Augusto Barbera, Giulio Prosperetti |language=Italian |publisher=Constitutional Court of Italy |date= |accessdate=4 April 2016}} Barbera was a lecturer of constitutional law at the [[University of Catania]] from 1969 to 1970. He then took up similar position at the [[University of Ferrara]], where he would remain until 1977. In that latter year he started working at the Institute of Public Law of the faculty of political science of the [[University of Bologna]]. He stopped working there in 1994. He was a professor of constitutional law at the University of Bologna. He took up [[emeritus]] status in 2014.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.magazine.unibo.it/archivio/2015/12/18/il-professor-augusto-barbera-alla-consulta-eletto-giudice-costituzionale |title=Il professor Augusto Barbera alla Consulta: eletto giudice costituzionale |language=Italian |publisher=Unibo Magazine |date=18 December 2015 |accessdate=7 April 2016}} In 2013 Barbera was named as one of 35 academics in a commission on constitutional reform under Prime Minister [[Enrico Letta]].{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.bolognatoday.it/cronaca/augusto-barbera-corte-costituzionale-prof-universita-bologna.html |title=Augusto Barbera, professore emerito di Alma Mater, eletto membro della Corte Costituzionale |language=Italian |publisher=Bologna Today |date=17 December 2015 |accessdate=4 April 2016}}{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.federalismi.it/document/04062013235208.pdf |title=Elenco dei componenti della Commissione per le Riforme Constituzionali nominata dal President del Consiglio Enrico Letta |language=Italian |publisher=Federalismi |date= |accessdate=}} Barbera is a corresponding academic of the [[Academy of Sciences of the Institute of Bologna]] in the section of law, economics, and finance. ==Political career== Barbera took up political office in 1976, when he was elected to the [[Chamber of Deputies (Italy)|Chamber of Deputies]] for the [[Italian Communist Party]]. He would stay member of the Chamber until 1994. When the Communist Party dissolved in 1991, he stayed member of its successor party, the [[Democratic Party of the Left]]. From 1987 to 1992 Barbera served as president of the parliamentary committee on regional questions.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.rainews.it/dl/rainews/articoli/Consulta-chi-sono-i-3-nuovi-giudici-che-hanno-rottamato-il-patto-del-Nazareno-4c27cd0d-4bc9-47ae-94a0-1393bc5d96ff.html?refresh_ce |title=Consulta, chi sono i 3 nuovi giudici che hanno 'rottamato' il patto del Nazareno |language=Italian |publisher=RAI News |date=17 December 2015 |accessdate=4 April 2016}} On 29 April 1993 Barbera was one of three former Communist Party politicians named in the new [[Ciampi Cabinet]]; the other two were [[Vincenzo Visco]] and [[Luigi Berlinguer]]. Barbera was made Minister without portfolio for relations with Parliament. It was the first time in 46 years that former Communist Party politicians were made part of the cabinet.{{cite web|author=Patricia Clough |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/ex-communists-join-italys-reform-government-the-non-political-prime-minister-puts-together-a-mould-1458094.html |title=Ex-Communists join Italy's reform government: The non-political Prime Minister puts together a mould-breaking cabinet |publisher=''[[The Independent]]'' |date=29 April 1993 |accessdate=6 April 2016}} Several hours after being officially named in the government, a rupture broke in the coalition over the handling of charges in Parliament against former Prime Minister [[Bettino Craxi]]. The Ministers of the Democratic Party of the Left, to which Barbera belonged, resigned.{{cite web|author=William D. Montalbano |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1993-04-30/news/mn-29230_1_corruption-scandal |title=Italy's New Leadership Splits Within Hours Over Scandal |publisher=''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' |date=30 April 1993 |accessdate=}}{{cite book|author1=Martin Bull|author2=Martin Rhodes|title=Crisis and Transition in Italian Politics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-5sAAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA52|date=5 March 2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-135-22274-1|page=52}} His replacement, [[Paolo Barile]], took office on 4 May.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.governo.it/i-governi-dal-1943-ad-oggi/xi-legislatura-23-aprile-1992-16-gennaio-1994/governo-ciampi/2968 |title=Governo Ciampi |language=Italian |publisher=Government of Italy |date= |accessdate=4 April 2016}} On 16 December 2015, the [[Italian Parliament]] elected three candidates to the [[Constitutional Court of Italy]]: [[Franco Modugno]], [[Giulio Prosperetti]] and Barbera. The election was realized after 31 previous failed attempts.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.ansa.it/english/news/politics/2015/12/17/constitutional-court-breakthrough_eed5c254-c43a-4060-9f1d-021ffa9d3112.html |title=Constitutional Court breakthrough |publisher=ANSA |date=17 December 2015 |accessdate=4 April 2016}} Barbera was the candidate of the [[Democratic Party (Italy)|Democratic Party]], he obtained 581 votes in favor.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.corriere.it/politica/15_dicembre_16/consulta-accordo-democratici-l-m5s-esclusa-forza-italia-2191ca42-a3fb-11e5-900d-2dd5b80ea9fe.shtml |title=Consulta, fumata bianca: eletti Modugno, Barbera, Prosperetti dopo l’accordo tra Pd e M5S: esclusa Fi |language=Italian |publisher=Corriere della Sera |date=17 December 2015 |accessdate=4 April 2016}} He was sworn in five days after his election. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Ciampi Cabinet}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Barbera, Augusto}} [[Category:1938 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Aidone]] [[Category:Italian Communist Party politicians]] [[Category:Democratic Party of the Left politicians]] [[Category:Democrats of the Left politicians]] [[Category:Democratic Party (Italy) politicians]] [[Category:Government ministers of Italy]] [[Category:Deputies of Legislature VII of Italy]] [[Category:Deputies of Legislature VIII of Italy]] [[Category:Deputies of Legislature IX of Italy]] [[Category:Deputies of Legislature X of Italy]] [[Category:Deputies of Legislature XI of Italy]] [[Category:Judges of the Constitutional Court of Italy]] [[Category:Scholars of constitutional law]] [[Category:University of Bologna faculty]] [[Category:University of Catania faculty]] [[Category:University of Ferrara faculty]]

The '''Belgrade six''' is a name of the group of six Serbian intellectuals arrested in [[Belgrade]], [[Yugoslavia]], in 1984 and charged with counterrevolutionary activity.
== Members of the group == The group consisted of:<ref>{{cite book|last=Magaš|first=Branka|title=The destruction of Yugoslavia : tracking the break-up 1980-92|year=1993|publisher=Verso|location=London ; New York|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=d5np99Vgc0YC&pg=PA102 |accessdate=28 July 2012|page=102|quote=In August 1984, six Yugoslav intellectuals - Pavle Imsirovic, Gordan Jovanovic, ... Milan Nikolic and Dragomir Olujic - were charged jointly with forming a 'counterrevolutionary organization aimed at the overthrow of the constitutional order'.}}</ref> * [[Miodrag Milić]] * Milan Nikolić * [[Dragomir Olujić]] * [[Vladimir Miljanović]] * [[Gordan Jovanović]] * [[Pavluško Imširović]]
== Trial == The trial was held between 5 November 1984 and 4 February 1985. It had significant media coverage.<ref>{{cite book |title= The Lessons of Yugoslavia |last=Spencer |first= Metta |authorlink= |year=2000 |publisher= |location= |isbn= |page=122 |pages= |accessdate=July 28, 2012 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1Z5aT8Z-2XYC&pg=PA122 }}</ref> One of defence attorneys was [[Vladimir Šeks]].<ref>{{cite book|last=|first=|title=The South Slav journal, Volume 9-10|year=1987|publisher=Dositey Obradovich Circle|location=London ; New York|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CBpXAAAAYAAJ&q=%22belgrade+six%22+olujic&dq=%22belgrade+six%22+olujic&source=bl&ots=d6TfHa5hjJ&sig=mF-GYE-7LNTpOQjIdkgDR-n8iWg&hl=en&sa=X&ei=pMETUJK0EsfysgbHzoCoAg&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAg|author=|accessdate=28 July 2012|pages=57, 64|quote=The trial of the "Belgrade Six", held from 5th November 1984 to 4th February 1985,... "Belgrade Six" defense attorney Vladimir Seks}}</ref>
Cases against Nikolić, Milić and Olujić were separated from the cases of other member of the group. They were sentenced to between one and two-year prison terms.<ref>{{cite book |title= Advocating Dignity: Human Rights Mobilizations in Global Politics |last= Quataert |first=Jean H. |authorlink= |year=2009 |publisher= University of Pennsylvania Press |location= Philadelphia |isbn= 9780812241631 |page=105 |pages= |accessdate=July 28, 2012 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tqmmf-gNpmMC&pg=PA105 }}</ref>

{{Infobox organization | name = Black Women's Defense League | logo = File:Black Women's Defense.jpg League logo.jpg | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | predecessor = | merged = | successor = | formation = {{start date and age|2015}} | founding_location = | extinction = <!-- use {{end date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | merger = | type = | status = | purpose = | headquarters = | location = [[Dallas]], [[Texas]], [[United States]] | methods = [[Self-defense]] and firearms training, political education, charity, youth outreach, hurricane relief, protests | fields = | membership = | membership_year = | language = | owner = <!-- or | owners = --> | sec_gen = | leader_title = Founder | leader_name = Niecee X | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | key_people = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | subsidiaries = | secessions = | affiliations = | slogan = | mission = | website = | remarks = | formerly = | footnotes = }} The '''Black Women's Defense League''' (BWDL) is a [[self-defense]] organization based in [[Dallas]], [[Texas]], [[United States]].<ref name=cooper>{{cite web|url=https://www.vice.com/en_uk/article/ypqy9w/this-group-of-black-women-is-taking-up-arms-to-fight-racism-and-misogyny|title=This Group of Black Women Is Taking Up Arms to Fight Racism and Misogyny|date=February 9, 2017|accessdate=September 3, 2017|work=[[Vice (magazine)|Vice]]|first=Wilbert L.|last=Cooper}}</ref>
==Overview==
The BWDL was founded in 2015<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/apr/27/black-women-guns-classes-racism-trump|title=More black women are learning to use guns: 'this is a movement, and it starts now'|date=April 27, 2017|accessdate=September 3, 2017|work=[[The Guardian]]|first=Timothy|last=Pratt}}</ref> by Niecee X.<ref name=cooper/> She was influenced by groups including the [[Huey P. Newton Gun Club]] but later split from them.<ref name=cooper/>
The BWDL describes itself as a [[Womanist]] organization.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blavity.com/the-black-womens-defense-league-stands-its-ground-at-the-intersection-of-race-and-feminism|title=How The Black Women's Defense League Is Confronting Racism and Misogny Head-On|date=February 2017|accessdate=September 3, 2017|work=[[Blavity]]|first=Ebony|last=F.}}</ref> According to the group's [[Facebook]] page, it "works for the immediate pursuit of an [[intersectional]], safe, and free society" and "organizes to provide immediate protection and services to Black Women and those most marginalized by [[White Supremacy]]."<ref name=sanoff>{{cite web|url=https://hellogiggles.com/news/politics/niecee-x-farmer-mai-america-dreaming/|title=These women are fighting to make the American Dream a reality for everyone|date=July 17, 2018|accessdate=August 6, 2018|work=[[HelloGiggles]]|first=Rachel|last=Sanoff}}</ref> The group provides [[self-defense]] and arms training to "abused, underserved black women and marginalized genders",<ref>{{cite web|url=https://psmag.com/social-justice/fascinating-history-of-leftist-self-defense|title=The long, fascinating history of leftist self-defense|date=July 28, 2017|accessdate=September 3, 2017|work=[[Pacific Standard]]|first=Elizabeth|last=King}}</ref> and also engages in political education, charity work and youth outreach work.<ref name=sanoff/>
==Activities==
In January 2017 BWDL members attended the [[2017 Women's March|Women's March]] in Washington, D.C.<ref name=cooper/>
In September 2017 the group was involved in relief efforts in [[Houston]], [[Port Arthur, Texas|Port Arthur]] and [[Beaumont, Texas]], following [[Hurricane Harvey]].<ref name=sanoff/><ref name=gosztola>{{cite web|url=https://shadowproof.com/2017/09/10/unauthorized-disclosure-episode-31-black-women-hurricane-harvey-relief/|title=After hurricane, Black Women's Defense League focuses on relief for communities of color in Houston|date=September 10, 2017|accessdate=September 13, 2017|work=[[ShadowProof]]|first=Kevin|last=Gosztola}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://inthesetimes.com/article/20522/hurricane-harvey-houstin-leftist-mutual-aid-redneck-revolt|title=Leftists to the Rescue: Where the State and Big NGOs Fail, Mutual Aid Networks Step In|date=September 14, 2017|accessdate=September 16, 2017|work=[[In These Times]]|first=Jared|last=Ware}} </ref> Its activities focused on groups otherwise overlooked by relief organizations and those excluded by shelters.<ref name=gosztola/>
In December 2017 the BWDL organised a protest against a concert by [[R. Kelly]] in Dallas due to accusations of sexual misconduct.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fox4news.com/news/womens-group-wants-r-kelly-concert-in-dallas-canceled|title=Women's group wants R-Kelly concert in Dallas canceled|date=November 27, 2017|accessdate=August 5, 2018|publisher=[[KDFW|Fox 4]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://cw39.com/2017/12/05/r-kelly-greeted-by-protesters-at-dallas-concert/|title=R. Kelly greeted by protesters at Dallas concert|date=December 5, 2017|accessdate=August 5, 2018|publisher=[[KIAH|CW39 Houston]]}}</ref>
In May 2018 the BWDL was featured in a documentary produced by [[Pabst Blue Ribbon]], which sought to celebrate "the voices of today's ever-evolving [[American dream]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://mic.com/articles/189464/pabst-blue-ribbon-is-the-latest-brand-to-wade-into-the-world-of-vague-political-messaging|title=Pabst Blue Ribbon is the latest brand to wade into the world of vague political messaging|date=May 23, 2018|accessdate=August 6, 2018|work=[[Mic (media company)|Mic]]|first=Kate|last=Bratskeir}}</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=October 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2018}} {{more references|date=October 2014}} [[File:Bodleian Law Library.JPG|thumb|Stairs leading to the Bodleian Law Library.]] {{Location map |Oxford (central) |label=Bodleian
Law Library |position=left |label_size=120 |mark=Blue pog.svg |marksize=12 |lat=51.7570 |long=-1.2477 |width=225 |float=right |caption=Location of the Bodleian Law Library within central Oxford }} The '''Bodleian Law Library''' ('''BLL''') is an [[academic library]] in [[Oxford]], England.{{cite book | title=[[The Encyclopaedia of Oxford]] | publisher=[[Macmillan Publishers|Macmillan]] | chapter=Law Library | year=1988 | page=216 | isbn=0-333-39917-X | editor-last=Hibbert |editor-first=Christopher |editor-link=Christopher Hibbert }} It is part of [[Oxford University]], the [[Bodleian Library|Bodleian Libraries]] and is also the library of the Faculty of Law. It is situated in part of the [[listed building|Grade II*-listed]] St Cross Building{{Cite web|url=http://www.buildingcentre.co.uk/case_study/st-cross-building-oxford|title=St Cross Building, Oxford|website=''buildingcentre.co.uk''|access-date=24 March 2016}} on [[St Cross Road]] in the parish of [[Holywell, Oxford|Holywell]], on the corner of [[Manor Road, Oxford|Manor Road]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.law.ox.ac.uk/about-us/about-faculty/st-cross-building|title=St Cross Building|website=Oxford Law Faculty|access-date=24 March 2016}} ==Overview== The library is one of the largest open-access law libraries in Europe.{{fact|date=October 2014}} Opened in 1964, it now{{when|date=October 2014}} contains over 450,000 volumes on 16,000 linear metres of shelving, and is housed in purpose-built library accommodation designed by the distinguished architects [[Sir Leslie Martin]] and [[Colin St John Wilson]]. The BLL benefits from the Bodleian's status as a library of [[legal deposit]], by which the BLL has the right to claim a copy of any printed legal material published in the United Kingdom or Ireland. Together with its position as an official Documentation Centre for the [[European Union]] and its significant expenditure on foreign legal materials, this means that the BLL adds more than 10,000 new items to its stock each year. The BLL serves a wide and expanding range of university and external readers.{{fact|date=October 2014}} Its primary 'client' base is the [[University of Oxford]]'s Faculty of Law which, with over 1,100 undergraduate and postgraduate students and 80 academic staff, is the largest law faculty in the United Kingdom. At the same time, and because of its legal deposit status, the BLL is also used extensively by legal firms, lawyers, and individual researchers from both home and abroad. The BLL collection supports the teaching and research of Law at the University of Oxford, and shares Criminology and Socio-Legal Studies with the [[Social Science Library, Oxford|Social Science Library]]. The St Cross Building is adjacent to the Social Science Building in Manor Road, which houses the Social Sciences departments, including the Economics Department, as well as the Social Science Library. ==Collection== The BLL collection has been built up over a period of four centuries, both from the legal deposit intake, and from specific purchases based on recommendations from academics and researchers alike.{{fact|date=October 2014}} The core primary legal materials for the UK, the Commonwealth countries, the US, the EU, individual European countries, and international law are collected on an ongoing basis, together with key legal texts for all jurisdictions. The BLL holds full sets of previous editions of major UK legal monographs on the open shelves. It receives over 2,000 [[periodical publication|serial]] titles per annum, including law reports, legislation, journals and looseleaf services from all the jurisdictions held in the collection.{{fact|date=October 2014}} The BLL holds several special collections, including rare books, the Viner collection, the Bandar Collection of [[Islamic Law]], and the Kahn-Freund collection of [[labour law]] material. Readers have access to all leading UK legal databases, together with a large number of foreign legal databases, supporting the research undertaken by members of the faculty.{{fact|date=October 2014}} Network printing, scanning and photocopying are provided. ==Facilities== [[File:Main Reading Room, Bodleian Law Library, University of Oxford - 20081018.jpg|thumb|Main Reading Room.]] The BLL was designed to hold the law collection of the Bodleian Library on open access shelves, ensuring ready access at all times to scholars.{{fact|date=October 2014}} Seating is provided for 430 readers, with over one third of seats reserved for postgraduate student use. There is a Graduate Reading Room.{{fact|date=October 2014}} This area occupies a separate wing, and provides students with [[ethernet]] access, several PCs, and wireless access for laptops. The BLL has a total of 40 [[Personal computer|PCs]] for reader use.{{fact|date=October 2014}}{{when|date=October 2014}} The PCs in the Freshfields IT room on the lower floor and in the Gallery computer room require readers to log in, but there are a few PCs for searching the catalogue on each floor. Wireless access for laptop computers is provided throughout most areas of the library and is accessed using the same login as the library PCs. The Baker McKenzie room is available for student use for group discussion, as well as {{linktext|carrel}} facilities which are offered on a shared basis.{{fact|date=October 2014}} ==Legal research== The Law Library staff provide an extensive teaching programme to all postgraduate and undergraduate students. The Legal Research Skills Programme is a compulsory first year subject for undergraduates;{{fact|date=October 2014}} all postgraduates are provided with detailed library induction, as well as a wide range of research classes offered each term. Legal information guides to specific countries and to legal subjects is available in leaflet form.{{fact|date=July 2009}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://www.bodleian.ox.ac.uk/law/_nocache Bodleian Law Library website] {{coord |51.7570|-1.2477|type:edu_region:GB|display=title}} {{Libraries of the University of Oxford}} [[Category:1964 establishments in England]] [[Category:Library buildings completed in 1964]] [[Category:Law libraries]] [[Category:Grade II* listed buildings in Oxford]] [[Category:Grade II listed library buildings]] [[Category:Libraries of the University of Oxford]] [[Category:Deposit libraries]]

{{Use Australian English|date=May 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox court case | name = Bunning v Cross | court = [[High Court of Australia]] | image = Coat of Arms of Australia.svg | date decided = 14 June 1978 | full name = | citations = [1978] [http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/cases/cth/HCA/1978/22.html HCA 22] (1978) 141 CLR 54 | judges = [[Garfield Barwick|Barwick]] CJ, [[Ninian Stephen|Stephen]], [[Kenneth Jacobs|Jacobs]], [[Lionel Murphy|Murphy]] & [[Keith Aickin|Aickin]] JJ | prior actions = | subsequent actions = none | opinions = Improperly or illegally obtained does not inherently render it inadmissible; however, it confers upon a judge a discretion to reject it (3:2) <small>(per Barwick CJ, Stephen and Aickin JJ; Jacobs and Murphy JJ dissenting)</small>. | transcripts = | keywords = Admissibility of evidence, improperly or illegally obtained evidence }} '''''Bunning v Cross''''' [1978] [http://www.austlii.edu.au/au/cases/cth/HCA/1978/22.html HCA 22], 141 CLR 54 (HCA), is an [[Australia]]n [[evidence (law)|evidence law]] case, in which the admissibility of improperly gained evidence is examined. Like the similar ''R v Ireland'' (1970) 126 CLR 321, ''Bunning v Cross'', the ruling of the [[High Court of Australia]] has been formulated as an [[exclusionary rule]], namely the onus is on the accused to prove the misconduct and justify exclusion,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lawlink.nsw.gov.au/lawlink/pdo/ll_pdo.nsf/vwPrint1/PDO_confessionalevidence|title=Confessional Evidence|first=Peter|last=Zahra|publisher=Public Defender's Office}}</ref> and is known as the Bunning discretion (cf. Ireland discretion).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alrc.gov.au/publications/16.%20Discretionary%20and%20Mandatory%20Exclusions/exclusion-improperly-or-illegally-obtained-e|title=Exclusion of improperly or illegally obtained evidence|publisher=Australian Law Reform Commission}}</ref><ref>Frank Bates. (1994.) "Improperly Obtained Evidence and Public Policy: An Australian Perspective", ''The International and Comparative Law Quarterly'', 43(2):379-91.</ref>
==Facts== Mr. Bunning was charged under s. 63 (1) of the ''Road Traffic Act, 1974'' with having driven a car "whilst under the influence of alcohol to such an extent as to be incapable of having proper control of it". Burton [[wiktionary:stipendiary|S]][[wiktionary:magistrate|M]] dismissed the charge, holding that the evidence of the result of a breathalyzer test was inadmissible because the police officer's requirement that the applicant undergo the test was unlawful.
The respondent (i.e., Cross, the prosecutor) sought and obtained an order to review from the [[Supreme Court of Western Australia]] under the ''Justices Act 1902'' (WA), as amended. The relevant provisions (ss. 197, 198, 205, 206, 206A and 206F) are set out in the judgment of the Chief Justice. Jones J heard the return to the order and decided that the evidence was admissible but that, in the circumstances, the magistrate was entitled in his discretion to admit or to reject it. Jones J declined to direct that the evidence should be admitted, but expressed the view that, if he were to decide the question for himself, he would admit it. He then made an order directing the magistrate to rehear the case and to determine it "in accordance with this judgment and according to law". This can only mean (and s. 206F makes this clear) that the magistrate was bound to follow Jones J's directions.
Burton SM reheard the case, treated the evidence of the breathalyzer test as admissible, and, in his discretion, rejected the evidence. He then dismissed the charge for the second time.
The respondent sought and obtained another order to review on the ground that the magistrate had not properly exercised his discretion. The Full Court (Lavan and Brinsden JJ, Burt CJ dissenting) held that the discretion was not properly exercised. Burt CJ held that the magistrate took into account all relevant matters. Lavan J took the view that Mr. Burton had not taken into account all relevant considerations and directed that he should reconsider the exercise of discretion. Brinsden J considered that the magistrate was bound to admit the evidence and thought the result should be a conviction. None of the justices of the Full Court was willing to exercise the discretion to admit or exclude the evidence, and none was willing that the Full Court should convict (although urged to do so by the respondent). They also refrained from directing the magistrate to convict.
==Judgment==
===Majority opinion=== Barwick CJ authored a [[concurring opinion]], and Stephen and Aickin JJ co-authored a concurring opinion. The majority ruled for the applicant, the prosecutor, and ordered the case to be remitted to the magistrate, who was directed to convict the respondent and impose upon the respondent an appropriate penalty.
===Dissenting opinion=== Jacobs and Murphy JJ both authored individual [[dissenting opinion]]s.

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} The '''Cartagena Declaration on Refugees''', or just '''Cartagena Declaration''', is a non-binding regional, i.e. Latin-American, instrument for the protection of refugees and was adopted in 1984 by delegates from 10 Latin-American countries: Belize, Colombia, Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Mexico, Nicaragua, Panama and Venezuela. The Declaration was since incorporated in national laws and state practice of 14 countries.
The declaration is the result of the "Colloquium on International Protection for Refugees and Displaced Persons in Central America, Mexico and Panama", which was held in [[Cartagena, Colombia|Cartagena]], [[Colombia]] from 19 to 22 November 1984. The Declaration was influenced by the "[[Contadora group|Contadora Act on Peace and Cooperation]]", which itself was based on the [[1951 Refugee Convention]] and the [[1967 Protocol]].
The Declaration reaffirms the importance of the right to [[Right of asylum|asylum]], the principle of [[non-refoulement]] and the importance of finding [[Refugee#Durable solutions|durable solutions]].<ref name="refugeelegalaidinformation">{{cite web|url=http://www.refugeelegalaidinformation.org/cartagena-declaration-refugees|publisher=refugeelegalaidinformation.org|title=Cartagena Declaration on Refugees | Rights in Exile Programme|accessdate=2017-02-06}}</ref><ref name="unhcr">{{cite web|url=http://www.unhcr.org/protection/expert/53bd4d0c9/summary-conclusions-interpretation-extended-refugee-definition-1984-cartagena.html|author=United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees|publisher=unhcr.org|title=UNHCR - Summary Conclusions on the interpretation of the extended refugee definition in the 1984 Cartagena Declaration|accessdate=2017-02-06}}</ref>
==Impact==
=== Extended refugee definition=== Compared to the 1951 Convention and the 1967 Protocol the Cartagena Declaration allows a broader category of persons in need of international protection to be considered as refugees. The Declaration, in Conclusion III, adds five situational events to the definition of the 1951 Convention and the 1967 Protocol. Similar additions were made in the [[1969 Refugee Convention]], but the Cartagena Declaration has further extended them. Refugees are those:
: "persons who have fled their country because their lives, security or freedom have been threatened by generalized violence, foreign aggression, internal conflicts, massive violation of human rights or other circumstances which have seriously disturbed public order".
This definition allows a broader temporal and geographical scope for the risks refugees find themselves in and additionally covers some of the indirect effects such as poverty, economic decline, inflation, violence, disease, food insecurity, malnourishment and displacement.<ref name="unhcr">{{cite web|url=http://www.unhcr.org/protection/expert/53bd4d0c9/summary-conclusions-interpretation-extended-refugee-definition-1984-cartagena.html|author=United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees|publisher=unhcr.org|title=UNHCR - Summary Conclusions on the interpretation of the extended refugee definition in the 1984 Cartagena Declaration|accessdate=2017-02-06}}</ref>
=== Improved cooperation between countries ===
The Cartagena Declaration was the beginning of an ongoing forum between Latin American countries. Since 1984 the signatories of the declaration meet again every 10 years and they have even extended its reach to include Caribbean countries. Three successor declarations were made: the 1994 San José Declaration, the 2004 Mexico Declaration and the 2014 Brazil Declaration (with 28 countries and three territories of Latin America and the Caribbean). No other continent or region has such a forum.<ref name="fmreview">{{cite web|url=http://www.fmreview.org/climatechange-disasters/maldonadocastillo.html|publisher=fmreview.org|title=The Cartagena process: 30 years of innovation and solidarity | Forced Migration Review|accessdate=2017-02-06}}</ref>

'''Chastisement''' is the infliction of [[corporal punishment]] as defined by law.
==Minors== {{see also|Corporal punishment in the home|School corporal punishment}} English [[common law]] allowed parents and others who have "lawful control or charge" of a child to use "moderate and reasonable" chastisement or correction. In the 1860 [[Eastbourne manslaughter]] case, [[Sir Alexander Cockburn, 12th Baronet|Alexander Cockburn]] as [[Lord Chief Justice of England and Wales|Chief Justice]] ruled: "By the law of England, a parent ... may for the purpose of correcting what is evil in the child, inflict moderate and reasonable corporal punishment, always, however, with this condition, that it is moderate and reasonable." It was left to the courts to decide what is meant by "moderate and reasonable" in any particular case.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.endcorporalpunishment.org/pages/progress/reports/uk.html# |title=Lawfulness of corporal punishment |access-date=2010-02-15 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100406023038/http://www.endcorporalpunishment.org/pages/progress/reports/uk.html# |archive-date=2010-04-06 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
The rights of parents, guardians and teachers, in regard to the chastisement of children, were expressly recognized in English law by the [[Prevention of Cruelty to Children Act]] 1904 (§ 28). A master had a right to inflict moderate chastisement upon his [[apprentice]] for neglect or other misbehaviour, provided that he did so himself, and that the apprentice was under age (Archbold, Cr. Pl., 23rd ed., 795).<ref name="Chisholm 1911, p. 189">{{ EB1911 |inline=1 |wstitle=Corporal Punishment |volume=7 |page=189}}</ref>
In [[England and Wales]], section 58 of the [[Children Act 2004]] enables parents to justify [[common assault]] or [[battery (crime)]] of their children as "reasonable punishment", but prevents the defence being used in relation to [[Assault occasioning actual bodily harm]] (i.e. when causing anything beyond "transient and trifling" such as bruising) and any more serious harm.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.endcorporalpunishment.org/pages/progress/reports/uk.html# |title=Lawfulness of corporal punishment |access-date=2010-02-15 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100406023038/http://www.endcorporalpunishment.org/pages/progress/reports/uk.html# |archive-date=2010-04-06 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
In [[law in the Republic of Ireland]], the [[rule of law]] allowing "physical chastisement" by teachers was abolished in 1997,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/1997/act/26/section/24/enacted/en/html#sec24|title=Non-Fatal Offences Against the Person Act, 1997, Section 24|work=[[Irish Statute Book]]|accessdate=21 November 2017}}</ref> and the common-law defence of "reasonable chastisement" by parents and guardians was abolished in 2015.<ref> * {{cite news|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/crime-and-law/ban-on-smacking-children-came-into-force-at-midnight-1.2461969|title=Ban on smacking children came into force at midnight|last=O'Brien|first=Carl|date=10 Dec 2015|work=[[The Irish Times]]|accessdate=21 November 2017}}; * {{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/2015/si/555/made/en/print|title=S.I. No. 555/2015 - Children First Act 2015 (Commencement) Order 2015.|work=[[Irish Statute Book]]|accessdate=21 November 2017}}; * {{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/eli/2015/act/36/section/28/enacted/en/html#sec28|title=Children First Act 2015, Section 28|work=[[Irish Statute Book]]|accessdate=21 November 2017}}; * {{cite web|url=https://www.kildarestreet.com/sendebates/?id=2015-10-21a.100#g107|title=Children First Bill 2014: Report|date=21 Oct 2015|work=Seanad debates|publisher=KildareStreet.com|accessdate=21 November 2017}} </ref>
==Wives== [[William Blackstone]] wrote in the 18th century in the [[Commentaries on the Laws of England]]:<ref>[http://www.lonang.com/exlibris/blackstone/bla-115.htm William Blackstone. Commentaries on the Laws of England]</ref> {{quote|The husband also (by the old law) might give his wife moderate correction. For, as he is to answer for her misbehaviour, the law thought it reasonable to entrust him with the power of restraining her, by domestic chastisement.... But, with us, in the politer reign of [[Charles II of England|Charles the Second]], this power of correction began to be doubted: and a wife may now have security of the peace against her husband; or, in return, a husband against his wife....Yet the lower rank of people, who were always fond of the old common law, still claim and exert their ancient privilege: and the courts of law will still permit a husband to restrain a wife of her liberty, in case of any gross misbehavior.}}
In the UK the traditional right of a husband to inflict moderate corporal punishment on his wife in order to keep her "within the bounds of duty" was similarly removed in 1891.<ref name="Chisholm 1911, p. 189"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lawteacher.net/family-law-resources/domestic-violence.php |title=R. v Jackson [1891] 1 QB 671, (abstract) |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140907012332/http://www.lawteacher.net/family-law-resources/domestic-violence.php |archive-date=7 September 2014 |website=LawTeacher.net}}</ref>
In the 1870s, courts in the United States overruled the common-law principle that a husband had the right to "physically chastise an errant wife".<ref>Calvert, R. "Criminal and civil liability in husband-wife assaults", in ''Violence in the family'' (Suzanne K. Steinmetz and Murray A. Straus, eds.), Harper & Row, New York, 1974. {{ISBN|0-396-06864-2}} p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=fCpHAAAAMAAJ&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=wife 89]</ref>
==See also== *[[Assault occasioning actual bodily harm]] *[[Castigation]] *[[Corporal punishment]] *[[Corporal punishment in the home]] *[[Domestic violence]] *[[Marital rape]] *[[South African criminal law#Disciplinary chastisement]]

{{Criminal procedure (trial)}} A '''deferred sentence''' is a sentence that is suspended until after a defendant has completed a period of [[probation]]. If the defendant fulfills the stipulations surrounding probation, a judge may then throw out the sentence and guilty plea, clearing the incident from their record. If the defendant violates probation, he or she must serve the full sentence immediately.<ref>{{cite web|title=Deferred Sentence|url=https://definitions.uslegal.com/d/deferred-sentence|website=USLegal|publisher=US Legal, Inc.|accessdate=29 August 2017}}</ref>
==United States== In the United States, a defendant must plead guilty to at least one of the crimes he or she is accused of in order to receive a deferred sentence.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Larson|first1=Aaron|title=Sentencing in Criminal Cases - Fines, Probation and Jail|url=https://www.expertlaw.com/library/criminal/sentences.html|website=ExpertLaw|accessdate=22 July 2017|date=1 September 2016}}</ref> The promise of a deferred sentence is often traded in exchange for a guilty plea in [[plea bargain]]s.
Deferred sentences are often given to first time offenders, or to those who have committed relatively minor crimes, although ultimately, the choice to defer a sentence is left to a judge's discretion.
===New York=== {{main|Adjournment in contemplation of dismissal}} In the state of [[New York (state)|New York]], a similar process is known as [[adjournment in contemplation of dismissal]] (ACOD). What typically happens in such a case is that the potential sentence is deferred for six months, and if the defendant stays out of trouble, the charge is dropped entirely with no public record of the offense.<ref>{{cite web|title=Adjournment in Contemplation of Dismissal Information Sheet|url=http://nassau18b.org/forms/adjournment_in_contemplation_of_dismissal.pdf|website=Nassau County New York Assigned Counsel Defender Plan|accessdate=22 July 2017}}</ref>
A deferred sentence is not exactly the same as an ACOD. One of the primary differences is that receiving an ACOD doesn't require an admission of guilt or plea of guilty unlike a deferred sentence which requires such. Upon completion of the ACOD, the charges are automatically sealed, fingerprints & mugshots are destroyed, and the arrest is annulled. There is no conviction and all rights you had prior to arrest are restored. In order to enter the deferred sentence program, a plea of guilt must be made. Even though successful completion of a deferred sentence results in a dismissal of charges and guilty plea withdrawal, most states still consider it to be a conviction since a plea of guilt was entered and you were considered "convicted" for the duration of the program. Furthermore, completion of a deferred sentence program usually requires a request to the court to have the underlying charges and arrest sealed.{{cn|date=July 2017}}

இலங்கை தேர்தல்கள் ஆணைக்குழு | seal = Emblem of Sri Lanka.svg | seal_width = 50 | image = | image_size = | image_caption = | type = Non-ministerial/Semi-independent Agency | formed = {{Start date and age|1955|10|01}}

Abeysekara | chief2_position = (Commission member) | chief3_name = Prof. Rathnajeevan Hoole | chief3_position = (Commission member) | chief4_name = R.M.A.L.Rathnayake | chief4_position = (Commissioner General of Elections/Director General Elections) | keydocument1 = 17th, 18th and 19th Amendments to the [[Constitution of Sri Lanka]] | website = {{URL|www.elections.gov.lk}} | map = | map_size = | map_caption = }} The '''Election Commission of Sri Lanka''' is the constitutional authority responsible for administering and overseeing all [[Elections in Sri Lanka|elections]] in [[Sri Lanka]], including the [[President of Sri Lanka|Presidential]], [[Parliament of Sri Lanka|Parliamentary]], [[Provinces of Sri Lanka|Provincial]] and [[Local government in Sri Lanka|Local Authority]] elections. Sri Lanka has had [[Universal suffrage|universal adult suffrage]] since 1931, becoming the first [[Crown colony]] to enfranchise all adult citizens, 3 years after the [[United Kingdom]] itself; the country is the oldest democracy in [[Asia]].{{cite news|last1=Rajakarunanayake|first1=Lucien|title=Seven decades of Asia’s oldest democracy|url=http://dailynews.lk/2017/10/04/features/130214/seven-decades-asia%E2%80%99s-oldest-democracy|accessdate=4 February 2018|agency=Daily News|publisher=dailynews.lk|date=4 Oct 2017}}{{cite news|title=Elections Department in the limelight|url=http://www.ft.lk/article/478461/Elections-Department-in-the-limelight|accessdate=4 February 2018|agency=Daily Financial Times|publisher=ft.lk|date=3 Oct 2015}} ==Early history== The recommendations of the [[Soulbury Commission]] of 1944 led to the country's 1948 'Soulbury Constitution', granting it independence with [[Dominion]] status within the [[British Empire]] through the Ceylon Independence Act of 1947.{{cite web|title=Ceylon Independence Act 1947|url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/Geo6/11-12/7/enacted|website=legislation.gov.uk|publisher=The National Archives of the United Kingdom|accessdate=4 February 2018}} The work of the Commission began in 1944, with several pieces of key legislation being enacted in the interim as a result of its work- of these, the Ceylon (Constitution) Order in Council of 1946 would lead to the 1948 constitution, while the Ceylon (Parliamentary Elections) Order in Council and the Local Authorities Ordinance enacted in the same year created two government departments that would eventually go on to form the Elections Commission.{{cite web|title=Our History|url=http://www.slelections.gov.lk/web/index.php/en/about-us/our-history|website=Official Website of the Election Commission of Sri Lanka|publisher=Election Commission of Sri Lanka|accessdate=4 February 2018}}{{cite web|title=A Reprint of the Ceylon (Parliamentary Elections) Order in Council, 1946 (CHAPTER 381)|url=https://aceproject.org/regions-en/countries-and-territories/LK/case-studies/the-ceylon-parliamentary-elecions-order-in-council.pdf|website=aceproject.org|publisher=Government of Sri Lanka|accessdate=4 February 2018}}{{cite web|title=Performance Appraisal Report of the Department of Elections/Election Commission for the Year 2015|url=https://www.parliament.lk/uploads/documents/paperspresented/performance-report-department-of-elections-election-commission-2015.pdf|website=Parliament of Sri Lanka|publisher=Sri Lanka Department of Elections/Elections Commission of Sri Lanka|accessdate=4 February 2018}} Section 88A of the Ceylon (Parliamentary Elections) Order in Council of 1946 established the Department of Parliamentary elections headed by a Commissioner and assisted by Assistant and Deputy Commissioners, with the responsibility of registering electors and the conduct of Parliamentary Elections. At the same time, the Local Authorities Ordinance, No. 53 of 1946 established the Department of Local Authorities Elections under a separate Commissioner and staff to oversee and administer all non-Parliamentary elections on the island. During its existence, the former oversaw two Parliamentary elections, in [[Ceylonese parliamentary election, 1947|1947]] and [[Ceylonese parliamentary election, 1952|1952]]. These two departments functioned independently of each other until 1 October 1955, when they were merged to form the Department of Elections; as was the case with its predecessors, the department functioned as an independent, non-ministerial institution answerable only to [[Parliament of Sri Lanka|Parliament]] and the [[Judiciary of Sri Lanka|Judiciary]]. ==Commissioners==
